Title: Benefits to University Students Through Volunteering in a Health Context: A New Model
Abstract: © 2017, © 2017 Society for Educational Studies.Individual interviews explored 50 British University students’ accounts of sustained volunteering within health settings and a model was developed using grounded theory. Phase one–‘Getting involved’–outlines ‘motives and catalysts’ for students starting to volunteer wherein altruistic motives of compassion for others are juxtaposed with perceptions of enhanced employability. Phase two–‘Maintaining commitment’–includes three components (‘Making connections’, ‘Developing resilience’ and ‘Keeping the balance’), which represent important aspects of continuing volunteering participation. Phase three–‘Reaping the rewards’–focuses on the benefits of volunteering including self-development. Our findings have implications for the training and support of student volunteers.
